Qst.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Qst.Quest: the information his Department has about safe incinerators; his views on whether such a concept is viable; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)
Speaker.P: Incineration is widely used internationally as a means both of disposing of different kinds of waste and of industrial and energy production. Incineration of waste and industrial/energy incineration are licensable processes or activities under the Air Pollution Act, 1987, and the Environmental Protection Agency Act, 1992. Licensing would embody appropriate conditions to prevent and limit pollution and must, inter alia, be based on use of best practicable means or of best available technology not entailing excessive costs.

EC legislation also sanctions the use of incineration on the basis of strict controls designed to ensure the protection of health and the environment. Council Directive 89/369/EEC provides for emission standards and other controls to prevent and limit air pollution from municipal waste incineration plants. A draft Directive providing for control of hazardous waste incineration is currently being examined by COREPER. EC directives also provide for specific limits on emissions arising from large combustion plants and plants which burn waste oils as fuel.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of continuing tragedies caused by house fires and the United States experience where legislation has resulted in smoke detectors being fitted in four out of five homes and domestic fire deaths have almost halved, he will make regulations under the Building Control Act requiring fire alarms to be provided in new buildings; if he will ensure that housing authorities do likewise in relation to public authority housing; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)
Speaker.P: Part B of the First Schedule to the Building Regulations, 1991, sets out requirements in relation to the fire precautions to be provided for in the design and construction of buildings. Guidance in relation to compliance with these requirements is contained in Technical Guidance Document B published under articles five of the Regulations. Houses designed and constructed in accordance with this document must be fitted with smoke detectors.

As regards existing local authority housing, while the primary responsibility for ensuring fire safety rests with each household, local authorities have been advised to actively encourage their tenants to provide and keep in good working order suitable domestic smoke detectors to approved standards.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - National Waste Management Policy.

Qst.Quest: the position in relation to the development of a national waste management policy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: , Wexford): Irish waste management policy has developed continuously in line with that of the European Communities, and rests on the strict enforcement of relevant EC and national legislation in accordance with local authority waste management plans. The Programme for a Partnership Government contains a specific commitment to the early introduction of a Waste Bill, which will provide a comprehensive framework for the evolution and implementation of future waste management policies.

A national perspective on waste policy was outlined in the informal Discussion Paper on Waste published by my Department in July 1992 and the views expressed by a wide range of interested organisations on the issues involved are being taken into account in the preparation of the legislation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Schools Environmental Awareness Programme.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to develop a comprehensive environmental awareness programme in schools; if he will consult the Minister for Education on the matter; and if he sees a role for ENFO in such a programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: , Wexford): My Department provides a widely based environmental awareness service through ENFO, which is extensively availed of by schools. Information packs on environmental issues are compiled and distributed to schools; school groups are encouraged to visit ENFO to view educational exhibitions and to use ENFO facilities; supplies of ENFO information leaflets are sent on request to teachers and students; and videos are given on loan to teachers. The ENFO centre is also made available for the presentation of teacher training courses on environmental topics. Each month, ENFO sponsor the placing of environmental inserts in school magazines which are distributed to approximately one third of all primary level school children. ENFO will continue with measures such as these so as to develop better links and support services for teachers and teacher centres and to facilitate teachers and students who wish to undertake studies or projects on the environment.
I am already in consultation with the Minister for Education about enhancing the environmental awareness dimension in the formal education of our young people.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne

Qst.Quest: the EC countries which have a Government airport tax, and whether such tax applies to the nationals of these countries.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The information requested is not immediately available; however, it is being sought from the other member states of the EC and I will forward it to the Deputy as soon as it comes to hand.

The position in Ireland is that a travel tax of £5 applies to passenger tickets issued in the State for travel, whether by sea or by air, to a destination outside the State, other than to Northern Ireland. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - INTERREG Programme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the criteria that were used in deciding which areas and counties would qualify for eligibility under the INTERREG Programme; and the reason certain counties were chosen as border counties, even though they did not touch the border, while other counties close to the border, such as County Meath, were excluded.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: INTERREG is a Structural Fund Community initiative designed to promote the implementation of certain Community objectives in relation to the special development problems of Border areas. Ireland and Northern Ireland have a joint programme under the initiative.

MainHeading.P: The final determination of areas to be covered under INTERREG was a matter for the EC Commission. The Commission used the NUTS III regional classification for the purposes of defining the eligible area. In the case of Ireland and NUTS III level regions are the former planning regions, and those adjacent to the Border were included. These were Donegal, the North East, Cavan, Monaghan, Louth, and the North West, Sligo, Leitrim. Under paragraphs 9 and 10 of the INTERREG guidelines some flexibility was allowed in respect of a limited number of measures such as co-operation networks and road infrastructures. This allowed for the inclusion of some suitable projects in areas outside but contiguous to the eligible area, that is parts of Meath, Roscommon and Longford.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: when, in view of the fact that the Maastricht Treaty states that a decision on the location of the European Monetary Institute should have been taken before the end of 1992, he expects this decision will actually be taken; and the implications of the delay in taking this decision.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The decision on the establishment of the EMI is a matter for the Heads of State or Government under Article 13 of the Protocol on the Statute of the European Monetary Institute (EMI) in the Treaty.
The next meeting of the Heads of State or Government will take place in June. The items for discussion at that meeting have as yet to be decided.

The EMI is an important and significant step on the road to Economic and Monetary Union. We have always supported progress towards European Monetary Union and I hope the decision on the establishment of the EMI can be taken soon.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Entitlements of Old Age Pensioners.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the nonpayment of free telephone rental allowance and other benefits to Irish people who have returned to this State and who are in receipt of British pensions but whose income may be lower than persons receiving pensions paid by this State; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The free schemes administered by my Department, such as free telephone rental allowance, free electricity allowance and free television licence, are available to people who are in receipt of social welfare type pensions and who are living alone or only with certain exempted people. People in receipt of social security pensions from Britain or from other EC countries or from countries with which Ireland has a bilateral social security agreement and who satisfy the living-alone conditions may also qualify for these allowances.

MainHeading.P: People in receipt of Irish or British occupational pensions at a rate less than normal social welfare levels and who have no other income may qualify for a reduced rate old age (non-contributory) pension, subject to satisfying the relevant means test. Receipt of that pension, even at a reduced rate, would bring them within the scope of the free schemes mentioned.
All people over 66 years of age and resident in the State are entitled to free travel under my Department's scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Director of Consumer Affairs that in January 1992 there were 274 petrol retail outlets in Dublin. The Director has indicated that comparison figures for 1987 and 1982 are not available.

When the Competition Act, 1991 was brought into force in October 1991 price control on petroleum products was lifted and the Restrictive Practices (Motor Spirits) Order, 1981 was revoked. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Motor Insurance Costs.

Qst.Quest: if the interdepartmental committee set up by the previous Government has concluded its report relating to the cost of motor insurance with particular reference to the measures or proposals to reduce this cost; if he will quantify the benefits to the motorist; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: The measures identified by the former Inter-Ministerial Group on Motor Insurance (IMG) designed to improve the cost environment for insurance addressed the problems of the high claims frequency and the costs, mainly legal costs, associated with the settlement of personal injury claims.

Thus, the measures were aimed at reducing the road accident rate, the incidence of dangerous, drunken and uninsured driving and the effectiveness and the efficiency of the legal system in the settling of personal injury actions in the Courts. Responsibility for the implementation of the measures, whether by legislation or otherwise, rests with the Ministers for the Environment and Justice.

A comprehensive list of the measures identified by the IMG were given in this House, most notably on 2nd and 3rd of July, 1991. The main items identified by the IMG include a number of positive proposals by the Minister for Justice, in relation to strict and sustained enforcement of existing road traffic legislation (via the Gardaí), the Courts (No. 2) Act which increased the jurisdiction of the lower courts and the proposed Court and Court Officers Bill which is designed to further improve the operation of the courts. In addition the Minister for the Environment proposes amendments to the Road Traffic Acts designed to reduce the accident rate and a new Road Traffic Bill which will introduce harsher penalties for dangerous, drunken and uninsured driving, including the impounding of uninsured vehicles.

Despite the relative success of a number of measures identified by the former IMG, I am convinced that we will not get a substantial reduction in premiums unless we cap awards for pain and suffering in insurance cases. I am not suggesting at all that people should not be compensated fully for medical, hospital bills and loss of earnings after an accident, but the balance of the award (the pain and suffering element) is totally out of proportion with the rest of the EC with average awards in Ireland almost 50 per cent higher than the UK and over 70 per cent higher than the EC average.

MainHeading.P: The IMG is being re-activated to continue to provide a focus for the identification and consideration of further measures having the objective of reducing insurance costs.

Clearly the benefits to motorists in terms of motor insurance premia will ultimately depend on the timing and the extent of their implementation and most importantly the attitude of the insurance industry, the legal profession, other professionals including doctors, and the general public including business and road users.

Qst.Quest: the main sources of toxic waste produced in this country; the amount of toxic waste from each of these sources; and the projected changes in the amounts of each type of toxic waste over the next decade.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne, Wexford)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: , Wexford): A full breakdown of toxic and dangerous waste arisings is set out in page 34 of the National Data Base on Waste, a copy of which is in the Oireachtas Library. More recent, but less detailed estimates made by my Department indicate that national annual arisings of toxic and dangerous waste stand at some 66,000 tonnes, of which organic solvents and chlorinated solvents represent 53 per cent and 19 per cent respectively. Over 70 per cent of the hazardous waste arisings in Ireland relate to the fine chemical/pharmaceutical/medical products sector.

A new classification of hazardous wastes is envisaged by Council Directive 91/689/EEC, which lists 40 categories or general types of hazardous wastes. As indicated in reply to Question No. 79 of 28 April 1993, this Directive also lays down a procedure, which has not yet been completed, for drawing up a list of particular hazardous wastes, having regard to specified categories, constituents and properties. Future projections of hazardous waste amounts will depend on this new classification.

Qst.Quest: the status which tree preservation orders have; the amount of protection they actually afford; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment (Mr. M. Smith)
Speaker.P: Tree Preservation Orders are provided for in section 45 of the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, as amended. If it appears to the planning authority that it is expedient in the interests of amenity to make provision for the preservation of any tree, trees, groups of trees or woodlands, they may make a Tree Preservation Order prohibiting the cutting down, topping, looping or wilful destruction of a tree, trees, group of trees or woodlands specified in the order except with the consent of the planning authority. A Tree Preservation Order (TPO) is a legally enforceable instrument and any person found guilty of contravening its provisions is liable, on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding £1,000.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: My Department has been involved in detailed and complex negotiations with the staff associations on the implementation of the proposals under the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy over the past few months. These are now almost finalised and I should be in a position to release the results of the Castlebar interviews shortly.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he will give the basis for correspondence (details supplied) from him which refers to a signature on a temporary convenience agreement in 1946 when in fact, the alleged signatory died four years earlier.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The operative events in this case took place some 40 years ago and full records on it are no longer available. Consequently, it is not possible to provide a detailed account of the history of the case.

From the limited information available it appears that an agreement was signed on 7 November 1946 and that the lands were vested in the deceased's widow on 13 July 1954. There is no clear indication as to who actually signed the agreement and in the absence of information to the contrary it was assumed that the individual referred to by the Deputy was the signatory. This assumption, through understandable, was mistaken and is regretted.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: when the special beef and suckler cow premia for December 1992, will be paid to farmers; the number of farmers who qualified; the total cost of the schemes; and the amount outstanding.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Approximately 62,000 applications for the Special Beef Premium Scheme and 15,600 applications for the Suckler Cow Premium Scheme were submitted to my Department in the period November/December 1992. These applications are being processed at present and payments are scheduled to commmence later this week. As all of the applications have not yet been processed, it is not possible to indicate the total cost of the Schemes or the amount outstanding.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: when the outstanding special beef and suckler cow premia for June 1992, will be paid to farmers; the number of farmers who qualified; the total cost of the schemes; and the amount outstanding.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Approximately 84,800 farmers have qualified for the Special Beef Premium Scheme in respect of applications submitted in June 1992. The total value of these applications is estimated at £31 million and the amount of grants outstanding is approximately £2 million.

With regard to the Suckler Cow Premium, some 75,600 farmers have qualified for the Scheme in respect of applications submitted in June 1992. The total value of these applications is estimated at £54.5 million and the amount of grants outstanding is approximately £1.5 million.

The bulk of the outstanding cases have been rejected at validation stage by computer, largely because of incorrectly quoted ear tag numbers. The queries on these cases are being resolved and payment will be made as quickly as possible where they are found to be in order.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Annuity.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: when farmers will be notified of the land annuity deal terms which were agreed in 1992; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh) Joe Walsh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. J. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Each farmer with a Land Annuity of £20 or more per annum should by now have been advised by letter of the amount which would need to be paid by 31 May, 1993 to clear off the annuity in full — this amount reflects the 50 per cent discount buy-out offer announced on 23 September 1992.

MainHeading.P: If any farmer with an annuity of £20 or more per annum has not received this letter because, for example, of a change of address that was not notified to my Department or for any other reason, he/she should contact by telephone or in writing the Collection Division of my Department, Michael Davitt House, Castlebar, County Mayo (Telephone 094-21100) as soon as possible and should quote the Receivable Order Number of the Land Annuity in question so that a replacement letter can issue quickly.

The annuity buy-out discount offer ends on 31 May 1993 so farmers wishing to take advantage of it would need to ensure that their payments reach the Collection Division of my Department in Castlebar by that date.

Farmers with Land Annuities of less than £20 per annum need not make any further payments on foot of these annuities from 1 May 1993 onwards as the annuities concerned have been written off with effect from that date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sale of Electrical Goods.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the claims made by the electrical trade that ESB shops enjoy an unfair advantage over other retailers in the sale of electrical goods; his views on these claims; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I am aware of concern expressed by retailers about the operation of ESB's retailing activities.

Steps were taken last year to ensure that ESB's retailing business operates on a more arms length basis from the monopoly electricity business. Since the September/October 1992 billing period customers making instalment payments for goods bought in ESB shops receive a new style invoice. This new format distinguishes clearly between payments for electricity supply and instalment payments for electrical appliances and states that supplies will not be cut off for failure to make repayments.

MainHeading.P: I consider that the change to the billing system has addressed concerns about ESB's retailing business and in particular the allegation that ESB may have been abusing its monopoly position by threatening to cut off supplies to customers who fell behind in appliance repayments.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if an analysis of the possibility of converting agricultural crops into methanol or ethanol for use as a fuel for engines has been carried out by his Department.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if his Department or any other body in this country is carrying out research into the potential of methanol or ethanol for use as fuels for internal combustion engines; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 119 and 120 together.

Research is being undertaken, primarily by Teagasc, on the possibilities of converting agricultural crops to transport fuels. The potential for alternative fuel use in transport is of interest to my Department and is the subject of a seminar which is being organised by EOLAS for 10 June next.
The potential for energy use of biomass generally is also being considered by a committee set up by the Minister of State at my Department.

Qst.Quest: if he intends to service the general medical services to include the provision of alternative medicine for medical card holders; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: The General Medical Services scheme provides, without charge, general practitioner services, drugs, medicines and appliances to persons with full eligibility.

General practitioners participating in the GMS are required to provide all proper and necessary treatment of a kind usually undertaken by a general practitioner and not requiring special skill or experience of a degree or kind which general practitioners cannot reasonably be expected to possess.

Drugs and medicines which are considered necessary for any person receiving services under the scheme must be covered by a product authorisation and must be examined and accredited by the national Drugs Advisory Board. Alternative medicines and treatments are not eligible for reimbursement under the GMS scheme.
I have no plans at present to change policy within the GMS scheme in regard to any of these matters.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that there are major discrepancies in the pay of nurses working at a Cheshire Home (details supplied) and that of nurses in the local health board; if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that the pay of those working at the Cheshire Home is dependent on a block grant paid by the relevant health board; and the steps, if any, he intends taking to ensure that nurses, employed at one remove from the health board, enjoy the same rates of pay as those directly employed by the health board.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Howlin) Brendan Howlin
Speaker.P: In common with all Cheshire Homes, the Home referred to by the Deputy is an independent voluntary body over which my Department has no direct control. Neither the health boards nor my Department are involved in the recruitment, pay or conditions of employees in any of the Cheshire Homes. This is entirely a matter for the management of the Homes concerned.

I am, however, aware of the financial difficulties being experienced by some Cheshire Homes, including the Home referred to by the Deputy. I would hope to be able to provide some additional funding in the current year to enable health boards increase their grants to the homes.

I understand that the staff of the Home referred to by the Deputy have submitted a claim for parity with health board rates to the management of the Home. Negotiations on this claim which has been referred to the Labour Court are progressing at the moment. It would be inappropriate for my Department to intervene during the course of these negotiations.

Qst.Quest: her views on the failure of her Department to transfer certain staff to the Revenue Commissioners under the Government's decentralisation programme to the mid-west; the reason she has adopted this position; and if she will make a statement on the implications of this approach both for the staff involved and for the programme of decentralisation to the mid-west.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: The transfers in question were offered by the Revenue Commissioners and, as such, are essentially a matter for the Commissioners to implement. My Department has been willing at all times to facilitate the transfers. Certain difficulties which did arise have been resolved and I understand that the Commissioners are now proceeding with the transfers.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the threatened closure of St. John's School, Drogheda, County Louth; and her views on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Proposals regarding the re-organisation of St. John's (Junior) and St. Paul's (Senior) national schools, Rathmullen, Drogheda, County Louth, into a single co-educational unit have been under consideration in my Department. It is now understood that the local managerial authorities do not wish to proceed with the proposed re-organisation. The matter will be kept under review in the light of enrolment and staffing trends in both schools.

Qst.Quest: the policy of her Department in relation to the application of discipline in schools; if she has received any submissions on the re-introduction of corporal punishment; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: Some years ago, my Department issued a circular to the authorities of primary and post-primary schools containing “Guidelines Towards a Positive Policy for School Behaviour and Discipline” together with “A suggested Code of Behaviour and Discipline for Post-Primary Schools”.

School authorities were reminded in that circular that the managerial authority of each school is responsible for ensuring that a fair and effective code of behaviour, encompassing rules, sanctions and procedures, is drawn up and applied in the school.
The use of corporal punishment is forbidden. I have received no submission seeking its reintroduction and I do not propose to reintroduce it.

Qst.Quest: the progress that has been made in the improvement of dental education facilities in Dublin; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: A special Working Group comprising representatives of the Departments of Health, Education and Finance, the Health Boards and the Higher Education Authority is being set up to examine the present and future requirement regarding dental education and care in the Dublin area.
